description: In this series of videos, we will cover key concepts and best practices for designing a relational database. Many problems that arise in using databases can be traced back to poor initial design. We will walk through the entire design process, from initial concept, through the design phase, ending with a fully functional database.

We will walk through the entire design process, from initial concept, through the design phase, ending with a fully functional database.
name: Relational Database Design
subtitle: Database design principles

episodes.description: In this series of videos, we will cover key concepts and best practices for designing a relational database. Many problems that arise in using databases can be traced back to poor initial design. We will walk through the entire design process, from initial concept, through the design phase, ending with a fully functional database.
episodes.title: Overview

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Vonne introduce relational database design by discussing key terms and definitions.
episodes.title: History, Terms and Definitions

Hello everyone welcome to another

And I've just always love good

18

I mean, we're friends off camera and

19

And so,

I knew when you talked to me about I'm

21

And you can think of databases and

but is is so
super important everything relies on

storing data
>> It really does,

you look at our networks today and

All the data has to be stored somewhere,

I'm jumping a little ahead on

But it's super important to
make sure that you get it

right-
>> It is.

41

>> And we would be definitely

we're gonna start up with some basics,

44

But this is gonna be a lot of theories,

45

we're gonna talk about what

And it is extremely important,
I do get excited,

it takes a special kind of person I

48
00:02:39.410 --> 00:02:43.979
But if it is done properly in

00:02:43.979 --> 00:02:47.626
much easier down the road
>> And I think this is something that I

50
00:02:47.626 --> 00:02:51.104
have kind of figure out you said
it takes a special person, [LAUGH]

51
00:02:51.104 --> 00:02:51.631
>> [LAUGH]

52
00:02:51.631 --> 00:02:53.925
>> It is not a straight forward as I kinda

53

thought it would be, it's like,
I just want all these information.

54
00:02:58.880 --> 00:03:03.230
Let's just store it all together and
that's not how it's done.

55

>> Not anymore, it was originally, right?

56
00:03:05.580 --> 00:03:09.289
I mean, back before we had
relational database design or

57

relational database as a concept,
we did just that.

58

In fact, most of you out there probably

59
00:03:17.620 --> 00:03:21.565
That you're looking at or that you've
used or used through work and it's huge.

60

30 columns of information, thousands and

61

thousands of rows and sometimes that's the

62
00:03:31.450 --> 00:03:35.410
Maybe it make sense, but a lot of times if
we can get that out of that what we call

63

a flat file and into a database,
the ability to work with that data, look

64

retrieve data just what we want.

65
00:03:45.680 --> 00:03:47.830
All without having to

66

And that's really the key because Excel,
for example, and

67
00:03:50.730 --> 00:03:53.290
we have several video episodes on Excel.

68
00:03:53.290 --> 00:03:55.210
Excel is powerful, I love Excel.

69
00:03:55.210 --> 00:03:59.620
And Some of the things that it can

70
00:03:59.620 --> 00:04:02.870
But if we go back 30 years,
back into the 70s,

71

a spreadsheet was what was called a flat

72
00:04:08.960 --> 00:04:12.180
And there were lots of problems

73
00:04:12.180 --> 00:04:15.154
And we'll talk about some of
them as we go through, but

74
00:04:15.154 --> 00:04:19.680
let's talk a little bit about where these
relational databases come from, just so

75
00:04:19.680 --> 00:04:21.570
we got a little bit of background.

76
00:04:21.570 --> 00:04:26.305
Back in 1970 EF Codd,
was a gentleman mathematician,

77
00:04:26.305 --> 00:04:30.590
that proposed the idea of
a relational database.

78
00:04:30.590 --> 00:04:34.300
Now I'm not saying he the first one
because you know how it is in these types

79
00:04:34.300 --> 00:04:35.870
of scenarios.

80
00:04:35.870 --> 00:04:38.598
A lot of times it's named after
the person that made it popular or

81
00:04:38.598 --> 00:04:41.488
brought it to the attention not
the person that first thought of it.

82
00:04:41.488 --> 00:04:46.848
But EF Codd is known as the godfather or
the grandfather of relational databases,

83
00:04:46.848 --> 00:04:52.690
because he's the one who said, let's apply
mathematics to the way we store data.

84
00:04:52.690 --> 00:04:56.700
And he came up with this
relational model of storing data.

85
00:04:56.700 --> 00:05:02.970
And like I said, this was back in 1970,
and it changed a lot of things, it brought

86
00:05:02.970 --> 00:05:07.490
that concept to the forefront because
before that we were using just flat files.

87
00:05:07.490 --> 00:05:11.632
>> And it's more of like, cuz my whole
thing, put it all in one place and

88
00:05:11.632 --> 00:05:16.430
just make it like you said,
40 columns and 50,000 rows, and all that.

89
00:05:16.430 --> 00:05:21.517
And it's all in this one place but
the whole idea is

90
00:05:21.517 --> 00:05:27.710
to break it up into related pieces and
how they tie together.

91
00:05:27.710 --> 00:05:31.100
What is the common thread between those?

92
00:05:31.100 --> 00:05:35.970
Is that the general idea of how
the relational database design?

93
00:05:35.970 --> 00:05:36.820
>> It is, it actually is.

94
00:05:36.820 --> 00:05:39.230
If we are gonna define
a relational database,

95
00:05:39.230 --> 00:05:41.860
it's gonna be data
that's stored in sets or

96
00:05:41.860 --> 00:05:47.280
sets of data that are organized into
tables, that contain columns and rows.

97
00:05:47.280 --> 00:05:53.100
And then have relationships between
those tables that tie the data together,

98
00:05:53.100 --> 00:05:54.210
that will allow me to work with.

99
00:05:54.210 --> 00:05:56.750
If we look at my screen here,
I've got an example, this is

100
00:05:56.750 --> 00:06:00.960
an old spreadsheet that I've got laying
around that has a lot of data on it.

101
00:06:00.960 --> 00:06:05.080
The columns are a little squished because
some of the information I don't want to

102
00:06:05.080 --> 00:06:09.400
show on screen, but
this is a typical flat file.

103
00:06:09.400 --> 00:06:13.495
This is a rather large spreadsheet it
has a lot of rows not too many columns.

104
00:06:13.495 --> 00:06:17.525
But the problems you run into with
scenarios like this or data stored like

105
00:06:17.525 --> 00:06:22.285
this, is when you try to insert new
information, it becomes challenging

106
00:06:22.285 --> 00:06:25.825
because if you don't have every bit of
information you're gonna have blanks.

107
00:06:25.825 --> 00:06:28.845
Like I can see blanks here, and
those are gonna cause problems.

108
00:06:28.845 --> 00:06:33.835
If there's data repeated like this is,
let's say two companies were listed here,

109
00:06:33.835 --> 00:06:36.940
and then in another column they've
got their address listed there.

110
00:06:36.940 --> 00:06:39.710
Well, let's say that company
changes their shipping address.

111
00:06:39.710 --> 00:06:43.400
If I'm gonna update this file properly,
I've gotta find every place that that

112
00:06:43.400 --> 00:06:47.390
company is listed and update every single
one of them with their new address.

113
00:06:47.390 --> 00:06:51.160
If I don't, if I miss one or two,
I now have inconsistent data.

114
00:06:51.160 --> 00:06:54.630
And sometimes I'll see one address, but
other people might pull up a query and

115
00:06:54.630 --> 00:06:57.790
see a different address and
now we don't know which one is correct.

116
00:06:57.790 --> 00:07:01.210
>> Well, and
if you keep on going on that kind of idea

117
00:07:01.210 --> 00:07:03.960
there could be a whole other
column that has another address.

118
00:07:03.960 --> 00:07:07.570
And that could be the address of
the sales person or where they live.

119
00:07:07.570 --> 00:07:10.610
So now I have, wait is the address for

120
00:07:10.610 --> 00:07:14.470
the salesperson,
is the address for the customer?

121
00:07:14.470 --> 00:07:17.890
Cuz it's on the one place,
cuz you need all that information.

122
00:07:17.890 --> 00:07:18.611
>> Yep.
>> But

123
00:07:18.611 --> 00:07:23.140
it gets hard like you're saying
to kind of manage all of that.

124
00:07:23.140 --> 00:07:25.433
>> Yeah, what if the organization
has three locations, so

125
00:07:25.433 --> 00:07:27.510
do I have to have three separate columns.

126
00:07:27.510 --> 00:07:30.340
One for each address that they have and
what if all the other

127
00:07:30.340 --> 00:07:33.160
companies that don't have three locations,
all those are now gonna be blank.

128
00:07:33.160 --> 00:07:38.560
So inserting a brand new column just
to support one record updated and

129
00:07:38.560 --> 00:07:39.680
that's not efficient.

130
00:07:39.680 --> 00:07:42.540
>> And, maybe I would think well,
I would just go ahead and

131
00:07:42.540 --> 00:07:43.715
put it on another worksheet.

132
00:07:43.715 --> 00:07:47.320
Cuz if I'm working in excel I
could have multiple worksheets,

133
00:07:47.320 --> 00:07:51.890
so that's related to each other,
but it's not.

134
00:07:51.890 --> 00:07:55.497
I mean, that's where the kind of
flat thinking in my mind of not

135
00:07:55.497 --> 00:07:59.940
being a database person, I'm like but
look I have all these worksheet tabs.

136
00:07:59.940 --> 00:08:00.780
But they don't connect.

137
00:08:00.780 --> 00:08:01.445
>> They don't.
And

138
00:08:01.445 --> 00:08:06.800
that's where I say Excel is becoming very
powerful and it's very database-like.

139
00:08:06.800 --> 00:08:10.520
Because with Excel today,
we can have multiple worksheets,

140
00:08:10.520 --> 00:08:14.480
I can start doing some really cool things

141

it's almost like a database but not quite.

142
00:08:18.670 --> 00:08:22.497
It still has its limitations and it takes
a lot more work whereas a database,

143
00:08:22.497 --> 00:08:25.830
a relational database,
it's really what it's designed to do.

144
00:08:25.830 --> 00:08:27.500
It makes working with is so much easier.

145
00:08:27.500 --> 00:08:29.485
>> And I think it's common
as a misconception, and

146
00:08:29.485 --> 00:08:31.090
we say through a lot of our Excel shows.

147
00:08:31.090 --> 00:08:37.960
This is not a database,
like a technically defined database.

148
00:08:37.960 --> 00:08:39.580
Yeah, but have store information.

149
00:08:39.580 --> 00:08:43.910
But not in the sense of what we we're
going to talk about in this show

150
00:08:43.910 --> 00:08:48.670

about how it all ties together and

151
00:08:48.670 --> 00:08:49.990
how you have to build it.

152
00:08:49.990 --> 00:08:54.640
And it's hard, it's hard to think of it,
and it's because I'm so

153
00:08:54.640 --> 00:08:59.230
Excel driven, learning of all
these concepts, I'm like, okay,

154
00:08:59.230 --> 00:09:04.010
that makes sense, all right, but
it's hard to wrap your head around it.

155
00:09:04.010 --> 00:09:07.585
>> It is, and so we're gonna see how
databases can make storing data,

156
00:09:07.585 --> 00:09:10.970
retrieving data,
updating data a whole lot easier.

157
00:09:10.970 --> 00:09:14.363
And really, what we're gonna focus
in on in this class is not a,

158
00:09:14.363 --> 00:09:18.010
what's a good way to say,
we're not looking at any particular

159
00:09:18.010 --> 00:09:22.490
what we call
a Relational Database Management System,

160
00:09:22.490 --> 00:09:27.470
RDMS, like SQL Server, or
Access or anything like that.

161
00:09:27.470 --> 00:09:31.040
We're not getting into, we have episodes
in our library, if you wanna learn one

162
00:09:31.040 --> 00:09:35.290
of those particular relational database
management systems, that you can watch.

163
00:09:35.290 --> 00:09:39.020
What I wanna talk about in this series is
gonna be more about the database itself

164
00:09:39.020 --> 00:09:41.940
and designing that database and
making it efficient.

165
00:09:41.940 --> 00:09:44.980
Because what you'll find is people
start working with databases.

166
00:09:44.980 --> 00:09:46.020
Let's say you've been tasked,

167
00:09:46.020 --> 00:09:50.100
you're boss has come to you, you're the
one that maybe has the most experience or

168
00:09:50.100 --> 00:09:53.470
the most gumption and
they think you can get it done.

169
00:09:53.470 --> 00:09:56.410
So they say we need you to take all
this stuff that we've got in these Excel

170
00:09:56.410 --> 00:09:59.480
spreadsheets and make us a database so
that we can write queries, so

171
00:09:59.480 --> 00:10:03.430
that we can run reports, so we can pull
this information out when we need it.

172
00:10:03.430 --> 00:10:06.590
And so, you're left trying to get
that information in their database.

173
00:10:06.590 --> 00:10:10.900
And you can do it, right, because within
a database we're gonna have tables

174
00:10:10.900 --> 00:10:14.430
that are columns and rows, and they're
very much like a spreadsheet, right?

175
00:10:14.430 --> 00:10:17.440
A spreadsheet is a sheet with columns and
rows.

176
00:10:17.440 --> 00:10:19.230
But if it's not done properly,

177
00:10:19.230 --> 00:10:23.080
when you go to try to retrieve that data,
run your queries,

178
00:10:23.080 --> 00:10:27.410
run your reports, you'll find either
inconsistent or it just doesn't work.

179
00:10:27.410 --> 00:10:29.120
Your results will be inconsistent or

180
00:10:29.120 --> 00:10:32.290
it just doesn't work because it wasn't
designed properly in the first place.

181
00:10:32.290 --> 00:10:35.674
If we take the trouble to
set it up first correctly,

182
00:10:35.674 --> 00:10:38.520
everything else will work so much better.

183
00:10:38.520 --> 00:10:41.972
>> I always equate this to,
this is like the introduction chapter in

184
00:10:41.972 --> 00:10:46.053
your textbook you really should read,
but everybody skips over it [LAUGH] goes

185
00:10:46.053 --> 00:10:49.320
right to the middle and like,
well, how do I do this?

186
00:10:49.320 --> 00:10:50.790
And then, you're almost,

187
00:10:50.790 --> 00:10:55.910
you're making a detriment to yourself
because you don't understand concepts.

188
00:10:55.910 --> 00:11:00.287
So, if you just read the intro chapter,
understand those terms really, really,

189
00:11:00.287 --> 00:11:02.912
actually understand the terms and
the concepts,

190
00:11:02.912 --> 00:11:05.866
it's going to make the implementation so
much better.

191
00:11:05.866 --> 00:11:07.842
Cuz you don't want to get down the road,

192
00:11:07.842 --> 00:11:11.798
making a poorly designed database cuz
then everybody's gonna be calling you and

193
00:11:11.798 --> 00:11:15.830
blaming you that you did not organize this
properly, and I can't work with this.

194
00:11:15.830 --> 00:11:20.520
>> Absolutely, and
it is tempting to just fire up Access,

195
00:11:20.520 --> 00:11:24.590
new table, and just start entering
column names and start entering data.

196
00:11:24.590 --> 00:11:29.390
And you might get lucky, but most likely
it's not going turn out that well.

197
00:11:29.390 --> 00:11:33.584
Or it is gonna be more work as you go to
get it to work, whereas if you start out

198
00:11:33.584 --> 00:11:38.177
with a good plan in the first place, it
would be much smoother and more enjoyable,

199
00:11:38.177 --> 00:11:41.468
and maybe you will start to
enjoy databases as much as I do.

200
00:11:41.468 --> 00:11:44.650
>> Prior planning prevents poor,
what was that thing?

201
00:11:44.650 --> 00:11:46.380
Prior, goodness.

202
00:11:46.380 --> 00:11:48.950
>> Prior planning prevents-
>> Poor performance?

203
00:11:48.950 --> 00:11:51.170
>> P, poor, yeah, I don't wanna say it.

204
00:11:51.170 --> 00:11:52.090
>> A bunch of Ps.

205
00:11:52.090 --> 00:11:55.861
>> Yeah. [LAUGH] >> Do your homework,
plan ahead, and you will do okay.

206
00:11:55.861 --> 00:11:57.608
[LAUGH]
>> Think of a word, P, but

207
00:11:57.608 --> 00:11:59.050
poor performance.

208
00:11:59.050 --> 00:12:00.197
>> Yeah [LAUGH] yeah, that one.

209
00:12:00.197 --> 00:12:02.390
>> Yeah, yeah.
>> This is a PC show so we should be nice.

210
00:12:02.390 --> 00:12:04.320
So Mike, where should we start?

211
00:12:04.320 --> 00:12:06.258
I mean, we talked terminology, right?

212
00:12:06.258 --> 00:12:08.050
>> Right, exactly, so
a little bit of history,

213
00:12:08.050 --> 00:12:11.760
not that that's super important to your
design, knowing where it came from.

00:23:28.020 --> 00:23:30.610
We could have spouses,
relatives working for us.

447
00:23:30.610 --> 00:23:32.140
But the combination of first name and

448
00:23:32.140 --> 00:23:36.260
last name might give you a way to identify
the row that I wanna to retrieve.

449
00:23:36.260 --> 00:23:40.320
So I combine columns to make
identifiers within those rows as well.

450
00:23:40.320 --> 00:23:43.935
But in general sense, identifiers
just the way to identify the row or

451
00:23:43.935 --> 00:23:46.510
tuple like you're trying to retrieve.

452
00:23:47.750 --> 00:23:53.270
Index, unique or non-unique identifier
used to increase search speed.

453
00:23:53.270 --> 00:23:57.220
All right, so
we can add indexes to our tables.

454
00:23:57.220 --> 00:24:00.471
And if we think about,
you guys are familiar with an index,

455
00:24:00.471 --> 00:24:03.657
if you take a book and you wanna,
Find a particular topic,

456
00:24:03.657 --> 00:24:08.165
do you start at page one, and just kind
of flip through it and look for it?

457
00:24:08.165 --> 00:24:09.720
Or go back to the back to the index and

458
00:24:09.720 --> 00:24:13.920
look it up and go it's on page 432 and
go right to it?

459
00:24:13.920 --> 00:24:17.710
Well in index, think about a database
having thousands, and thousands of rows,

460
00:24:17.710 --> 00:24:19.990
and you're telling it to
go find this one row.

461
00:24:19.990 --> 00:24:21.970
All right,
well that can take a little bit of time,

462
00:24:21.970 --> 00:24:24.430
it has to go through all of those rows.

463
00:24:24.430 --> 00:24:29.160
If we have an index on that table, it
gonna make it much faster because in this

464
00:24:29.160 --> 00:24:34.400
is we don't have to go into the details
of how it stores the data in pages.

465
00:24:34.400 --> 00:24:39.770
And things like that, but just understand
that an index is simply away that we can

466
00:24:39.770 --> 00:24:43.850
add an identifier to speed
up the search process.

467
00:24:43.850 --> 00:24:46.200
So, that if I have
an index on last name for

468
00:24:46.200 --> 00:24:50.580
example, it will make it much faster to
find all the records, let's say I write

469
00:24:50.580 --> 00:24:55.770
a query I say I need all of the customers
who's last names starts with R, okay.

470
00:24:55.770 --> 00:24:57.720
Well if there's no
organization to the data,

471
00:24:57.720 --> 00:24:59.960
it's gonna have to go through 10,000 rows.

472
00:24:59.960 --> 00:25:01.100
Has to go through every one of them,

473
00:25:01.100 --> 00:25:04.200
to make sure it gets all of the R,
all of the way to the last one.

474
00:25:04.200 --> 00:25:06.360
Cuz there could be an R to very end.

475
00:25:06.360 --> 00:25:09.960
If there's an index on that table,
well all the Rs can be together.

476
00:25:09.960 --> 00:25:11.900
And I can go here's the first R,
here's the last R.

477
00:25:11.900 --> 00:25:14.500
Let me grab everything in between it,
and I'm done.

478
00:25:14.500 --> 00:25:17.053
>> And this is more like an internal

479
00:25:17.053 --> 00:25:18.208
process if,
>> It is,

480
00:25:18.208 --> 00:25:22.800
[CROSSTALK] It's not something that we're
going to, it's something that we add

481
00:25:22.800 --> 00:25:27.330
to an existing column typically,
we'll do an index on last name.

482
00:25:27.330 --> 00:25:30.443
Like, normally, and we'll talk more about
this as we get into the design process,

483
00:25:30.443 --> 00:25:34.370
but if we have a particular
column that we used to search.

484
00:25:34.370 --> 00:25:35.810
No matter what it is,

485
00:25:35.810 --> 00:25:38.570
then I can put an index on that column
to speed up the search process.

486
00:25:38.570 --> 00:25:41.050
>> Is it kind of like in
Excel where if I wanted,

487
00:25:41.050 --> 00:25:44.190
I would sort it by ascending order,
or whatever.

488
00:25:44.190 --> 00:25:47.665
Like you're saying with the R, and that
way it makes it easier for me if I okay,

489
00:25:47.665 --> 00:25:49.620
I need to go all the way down to here.

490
00:25:49.620 --> 00:25:51.470
So it's like an internal sort, kind of.

491
00:25:51.470 --> 00:25:53.680
>> It is, and
they can get kind of complex,

492
00:25:53.680 --> 00:25:57.740
some of them actually change the way
the data stored in the database,

493
00:25:57.740 --> 00:26:00.460
on the hard disk or
where ever you're storing it.

494
00:26:00.460 --> 00:26:03.650
Some of them don't,
it depends if it's unique or non unique.

495
00:26:03.650 --> 00:26:06.680
And we'll get into some of
that a little bit later.

496
00:26:06.680 --> 00:26:11.760
Primary key, a unique identifier
used to identify rows in a table.

497
00:26:11.760 --> 00:26:15.670
Now, we already defined identifier,

498
00:26:15.670 --> 00:26:20.330
a primary key is just
a special type of identifier.

499
00:26:20.330 --> 00:26:22.980
It's one that I guarantee is unique for
every single row.

500
00:26:22.980 --> 00:26:26.260
>> And maybe that example I was
using with laundry ticket of like,

501
00:26:26.260 --> 00:26:31.160
okay, somebody shouldn't have
the same laundry ticket number as me,

502
00:26:31.160 --> 00:26:32.830
because those are my clothes.

503
00:26:32.830 --> 00:26:34.680
>> Exactly.
>> And I don't want anybody else getting

504
00:26:34.680 --> 00:26:38.220
my clothes, so
that's why I have a unique ticket.

505
00:26:38.220 --> 00:26:41.200
>> Yep, you might have more than one

506
00:26:41.200 --> 00:26:44.260
batch of laundry that you've
taken to that cleaner, right.

507
00:26:44.260 --> 00:26:46.610
And you're saying I wanna
pick up this batch.

508
00:26:46.610 --> 00:26:50.180
Well, how do I identify that batch versus
the other two batches you've dropped off?

509
00:26:50.180 --> 00:26:54.540
That unique identifier, that ticket
number is not reused on any others.

510
00:26:54.540 --> 00:26:55.820
The other tickets will have your name,

511
00:26:55.820 --> 00:26:58.590
your address because
you're the same customer.

512
00:26:58.590 --> 00:27:01.260
But that particular order
has a unique identifier.

513
00:27:01.260 --> 00:27:03.490
And that's what we do within our,
I'm sorry,

514
00:27:03.490 --> 00:27:07.910
within our tables is each row
has to have a unique identifier.

515
00:27:07.910 --> 00:27:09.850
Otherwise, I can't identify the row.

516
00:27:09.850 --> 00:27:11.310
If there's nothing unique about it,

517
00:27:11.310 --> 00:27:14.500
there's no way to tell it apart from
other rows databases wouldn't work.

518
00:27:14.500 --> 00:27:18.610
So that is a very important type
of identifier of primary key.

519
00:27:18.610 --> 00:27:21.760
And then the foreign key in this kind
of concept it's gonna make a lot more

520
00:27:21.760 --> 00:27:23.590
sense when you see it in action.

521
00:27:23.590 --> 00:27:28.430
But a foreign key is a primary key from
one table, that appears as a column in

522
00:27:28.430 --> 00:27:36.010
another table, creating a relationship
between two relations, or tables, right?

523
00:27:36.010 --> 00:27:39.500
And this where we start getting
into relational database,

524
00:27:39.500 --> 00:27:43.250
because if I have data in one table, and

525
00:27:43.250 --> 00:27:48.690
I have data in another table but all of
it about employees, how do I relate that?

526
00:27:48.690 --> 00:27:52.060
If I can pull Von's personal
information from one table, but

527
00:27:52.060 --> 00:27:54.250
I have her work information
in another table.

528
00:27:54.250 --> 00:27:56.780
I wanna pull all
the information about Vonne.

529
00:27:56.780 --> 00:28:02.620
I have to have a way to marry those two,
or get the related information, right?

530
00:28:02.620 --> 00:28:04.810
And that's when you take
the primary key from one, and

531
00:28:04.810 --> 00:28:07.370
put it into another table and
it becomes a foreign key.

532
00:28:07.370 --> 00:28:10.312
>> This was the concept, and
it's a very basic concept, but

533
00:28:10.312 --> 00:28:14.035
this was the one was a little difficult
for me, because I'm like, well,

534
00:28:14.035 --> 00:28:16.760
wait you have it like it's
almost like duplicating.

535
00:28:16.760 --> 00:28:20.220
>> But I have it here, and I have it here,
but it's not exactly the same.

536
00:28:20.220 --> 00:28:24.030
But, I know, they relate to each other, so

537
00:28:24.030 --> 00:28:25.190
it's yeah,
>> Yeah.

538
00:28:25.190 --> 00:28:26.740
>> It's a little confusing at first,

539
00:28:26.740 --> 00:28:29.950
but, like you said, I think once you start
working with it a little bit more, and

540
00:28:29.950 --> 00:28:33.750
understanding how you have to,
split the data apart.

541
00:28:33.750 --> 00:28:36.330
Then that relationship that you're saying.

542
00:28:36.330 --> 00:28:38.340
>> Yeah.
>> It does make a little bit more sense,

543
00:28:38.340 --> 00:28:42.514
but it's been on many,
many episodes with you and Ronnie.

544
00:28:42.514 --> 00:28:43.270
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

545
00:28:43.270 --> 00:28:46.220
this learning like,
okay that's how you have to think of it.

546
00:28:46.220 --> 00:28:50.095
>> Yep, absolutely and as you said,
it will definitely be a little more clear

547
00:28:50.095 --> 00:28:52.985
as when we get some visuals to
go with this, so But this is

548
00:28:52.985 --> 00:28:57.370
where we start the relationships, right,
this is what creates the relationship.

549
00:28:57.370 --> 00:29:01.775
And let's talk about a relationship,
let's define it exists between tables or

550
00:29:01.775 --> 00:29:03.230
relations, right?

551
00:29:03.230 --> 00:29:07.810
Relations have relationships,
can be a one to one,

552
00:29:07.810 --> 00:29:11.020
one to many, many to many, usually a verb.

553
00:29:11.020 --> 00:29:14.540
And what this means is when we look
at the relationship, here's table A,

554
00:29:14.540 --> 00:29:18.950
here's table B,
in table A there's one record for Vonne.

555
00:29:18.950 --> 00:29:21.250
Let's say I've got Vonne's
employee information.

556
00:29:21.250 --> 00:29:25.660
Well she's only listed in there once,
she's an employee at this organization.

557
00:29:25.660 --> 00:29:30.770
And then in another table,
I have extra information about Vonne.

558
00:29:30.770 --> 00:29:35.093
They'll give you one record in there, then
it can track back it contains extra info,

559
00:29:35.093 --> 00:29:36.910
that's a one to one relationship.

560
00:29:36.910 --> 00:29:40.677
Or what if that other table
was shows that Vonne is done?

561
00:29:40.677 --> 00:29:43.400
Well, Vonne is done many,
many, many shows,

562
00:29:43.400 --> 00:29:48.095
when I create the relationship between
the employees table, and the shows table,

563
00:29:48.095 --> 00:29:53.750
Vonne will appear once in the employees
table, but many times in the shows table.

564
00:29:53.750 --> 00:29:57.230
That would be a one to many relationship
we expect it to to occur once and

565
00:29:57.230 --> 00:29:58.640
only once in this table.

566
00:29:58.640 --> 00:30:01.280
But it can occur many
times in this other table.

567
00:30:01.280 --> 00:30:02.870
>> Yeah, and
in that table that's describing me,

568
00:30:02.870 --> 00:30:06.880
it could be like what computer I'm using,
what's my birthday.

569
00:30:06.880 --> 00:30:11.960
But in that how many shows you do,
okay, well it connects.

570
00:30:11.960 --> 00:30:16.670
We could go ahead and pull that, but
it's yeah, they connect together.

571
00:30:16.670 --> 00:30:20.170
>> Exactly, it creates that relationship
between those relations, and

572
00:30:20.170 --> 00:30:21.140
the last one's a many,

573
00:30:21.140 --> 00:30:25.870
to many, which you can probably infer now
that there's gonna be multiple instances.

574
00:30:25.870 --> 00:30:30.440
In one table that are related to
multiple instances in another table.

575
00:30:30.440 --> 00:30:32.936
And that's a many to many,
and I'll be honest with you,

576
00:30:32.936 --> 00:30:35.400
we typically don't like
many to many relationships.

577
00:30:35.400 --> 00:30:40.315
>> I remember Ronnie, saying like you
wanna try to avoid that or do work around

578
00:30:40.315 --> 00:30:44.715
to make sure that it's almost like an
interpreter, between that to have it, and

579
00:30:44.715 --> 00:30:46.975
then it gets into joins, I know I'm
getting way ahead of myself, but.

580
00:30:46.975 --> 00:30:48.205
>> But no that's exactly right,

581
00:30:48.205 --> 00:30:51.795
because you'll find that many to
many's can break a lot of things, so

582
00:30:51.795 --> 00:30:55.545
we typically look at those as bad and
we wanna try to avoid them.

583
00:30:55.545 --> 00:30:58.735
Or when we see them,
we can just as you say fix them.

584
00:30:58.735 --> 00:31:02.525
>> And that's the whole reason why we have
this show is to make sure that we design

585
00:31:02.525 --> 00:31:08.610
everything properly, so we avoid those and
become pitfalls that people run into.

586
00:31:08.610 --> 00:31:09.920
Well, I don't know but you Mike,

587
00:31:09.920 --> 00:31:12.350
but I'm actually kind of
excited about all of these.

588
00:31:12.350 --> 00:31:16.620
I'd have a lot of aha moments, and
we're in a glossary [LAUGH] right now, and

589
00:31:16.620 --> 00:31:18.250
then going over a term.

590
00:31:18.250 --> 00:31:21.110
But I know you said that we have some
examples that we're gonna look at, so

591
00:31:21.110 --> 00:31:24.380
we kinda pulled all these together,
but what, I think we're gonna have

592
00:31:24.380 --> 00:31:27.582
to come back for a part two,
because we've just had too much fun.

593
00:31:27.582 --> 00:31:29.215
>> I know.
>> So we're gonna need to come back,

594
00:31:29.215 --> 00:31:29.730
is that okay?

595
00:31:29.730 --> 00:31:30.340
>> That works for me.

596
00:31:30.340 --> 00:31:33.190
>> All right, we're gonna go ahead and
wrap this one up.

597
00:31:33.190 --> 00:31:36.250
Signing off for OfficeProTV,
I've been your host Vonne Smith.

598
00:31:36.250 --> 00:31:36.910
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

599
00:31:36.910 --> 00:31:38.475
>> And we'll see you soon.

600
00:31:38.475 --> 00:31:46.497
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Mike and Vonne continue introducing terms and concepts in relational database design. They walk through a sample database to demonstrate concepts such as tables, primary key, foreign key, and relationships.
episodes.title: History, Terms and Definitions Part 2

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.367 --> 00:00:16.630
Hello, everyone, and welcome back to
another exciting episode of OfficeProTV.

3
00:00:16.630 --> 00:00:21.166
I'm your host, Vonne Smith, and we
are continuing on part two of our history,

4
00:00:21.166 --> 00:00:25.977
terms, and definitions, and now we're
going to demonstrate those definitions,

5
00:00:25.977 --> 00:00:30.511
and that's a lot of Ds, and here to help
us with the database designer himself,

6
00:00:30.511 --> 00:00:32.978
man I keep on going, is Michael Roderick.

7
00:00:32.978 --> 00:00:34.508
How you doing?
>> If you want to use my middle name,

8
00:00:34.508 --> 00:00:36.313
Darren, we can just keep
the Ds on going right along.

9
00:00:36.313 --> 00:00:37.146
>> There you go.

10
00:00:37.146 --> 00:00:39.066
Yes, we got Ds all around.

11
00:00:39.066 --> 00:00:41.902
So, [LAUGH] we've got that going,
but we're gonna go ahead and

12
00:00:41.902 --> 00:00:42.980
demonstrate, right?

13
00:00:42.980 --> 00:00:46.765
>> Yeah, in that first part we did we
talked about a lot of terminology and

14
00:00:46.765 --> 00:00:50.294
pieces, parts that kind of make
up our relational database, and

15
00:00:50.294 --> 00:00:54.465
I said I'd show you some of that, so
we can help that information sink in, and

16
00:00:54.465 --> 00:00:58.021
we ran out of time, so
that's where we're gonna start with now.

17
00:00:58.021 --> 00:01:02.481
>> We just had too much fun really,
and just to kind of preface,

18
00:01:02.481 --> 00:01:07.904
this is something that I know has
helped me, is just repeatedly listening

19
00:01:07.904 --> 00:01:13.677
to the terms that are used within database
design to really make it sink in, and

20
00:01:13.677 --> 00:01:19.284
so we're gonna go through and hopefully,
sink in a little bit more for you.

21
00:01:19.284 --> 00:01:21.502
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] That's alright, so

22
00:01:21.502 --> 00:01:25.459
as you get older, like me,
repetition is key to learning anything.

23
00:01:25.459 --> 00:01:28.360
All right so,
let's took a look at my screen here, and

24
00:01:28.360 --> 00:01:32.163
what I've got is a sample database
from Microsoft Northwind Traders.

25
00:01:32.163 --> 00:01:33.942
It's a fictitious company, and

26
00:01:33.942 --> 00:01:38.069
it's a very well developed database that
has a lot of stuff going on in it, and

27
00:01:38.069 --> 00:01:41.770
we're not diving into all of that,
and we're not learning Access.

28
00:01:41.770 --> 00:01:46.524
I know you and Ronnie have some great
shows on how to work with Access, so

29
00:01:46.524 --> 00:01:51.057
make sure you check those out, but
I wanna use it as a way to display.

30
00:01:51.057 --> 00:01:52.191
I'm gonna just pick a table here.

31
00:01:52.191 --> 00:01:53.779
I'm gonna take the employees table.

32
00:01:53.779 --> 00:01:57.950
So remember,
we talked about a relation or a table.

33
00:01:57.950 --> 00:01:59.376
Well, this is a relation.

34
00:01:59.376 --> 00:02:04.580
This is a relation in a database, and
you can see it's organized in columns,

35
00:02:04.580 --> 00:02:08.754
and rows, and do you remember
what the other name for a row is?

36
00:02:08.754 --> 00:02:10.739
>> It's a tuple?

37
00:02:10.739 --> 00:02:11.308
>> A tuple, very good.

38
00:02:11.308 --> 00:02:12.558
>> I almost said toople and
I'm like wait, no, I think it's a-

39
00:02:12.558 --> 00:02:15.187
>> [LAUGH] I could be pronouncing

40
00:02:15.187 --> 00:02:16.395
that wrong.

41
00:02:16.395 --> 00:02:17.050
Tuple, Tuple?

42
00:02:17.050 --> 00:02:17.927
I think it's a tuple.

43
00:02:17.927 --> 00:02:18.927
>> We're gonna go with row.

44
00:02:18.927 --> 00:02:19.448
>> Yeah.
>> [LAUGH]

45
00:02:19.448 --> 00:02:20.310
>> Yeah, we're gonna go with row.

46
00:02:20.310 --> 00:02:21.900
There we go.

47
00:02:21.900 --> 00:02:24.490
So yeah, this will be a tupple,
or a row, or

48
00:02:24.490 --> 00:02:28.800
an instance of an object that
I'm trying to track, okay?

49
00:02:28.800 --> 00:02:34.458
So, for example, we can see that this
particular row is Northwind Traders versus

50
00:02:34.458 --> 00:02:40.372
last name Sirgenko, Maria, and there's
a email address, sales representative.

51
00:02:40.372 --> 00:02:44.587
Notice every one of these has to
do with this particular employee.

52
00:02:44.587 --> 00:02:48.132
>> You had to pick the row that has
the [LAUGH] hardest name to pronounce.

53
00:02:48.132 --> 00:02:49.940
It couldn't be just like Tom Jones.

54
00:02:49.940 --> 00:02:52.292
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, no no.

55
00:02:52.292 --> 00:02:52.840
I like that.

56
00:02:52.840 --> 00:02:55.490
It's challenging, right?

57
00:02:55.490 --> 00:02:58.733
So that entire row has to do
with one particular employee.

58
00:02:58.733 --> 00:03:03.381
Here's another entity or object that
we're tracking is Steven Thorp,

59
00:03:03.381 --> 00:03:07.341
with his email address,
his job title, his business phone,

60
00:03:07.341 --> 00:03:10.560
his home phone,
his mobile phone, etc., etc.

61
00:03:10.560 --> 00:03:16.709
So we see how a row is an instance
of an entity within our database.

62
00:03:16.709 --> 00:03:20.677
>> And this relation is the employee's?

63
00:03:20.677 --> 00:03:23.447
>> This is the employee's relation,
or the employee's table, exactly.

64
00:03:23.447 --> 00:03:27.610
>> Yes, so we're going to be storing
information about the employee,

65
00:03:27.610 --> 00:03:31.288
not sales or anything that's,

episodes.description: Data normalization is important in designing a database. In this episode, Mike and Vonne define the different normal forms and discuss anomalies that you want to avoid.
episodes.title: Data Normalization

episodes.description: Mike and Vonne continue to discuss data normalization, specifically demonstrating first normal form (1NF)
episodes.title: Data Normalization Part 2

episodes.description: Mike and Vonne wrap up data normalization, specifically demonstrating second (2NF) and third normal form (3NF).
episodes.title: Data Normalization Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Vonne start to plan out a database for their fictitious company. They draft a statement of purpose for the database, which helps determine what tables will be needed. They also  review what steps a database designer would need to take when designing for others, such as what questions to ask and how to talk to stakeholders to determine their information tracking needs.
episodes.title: Designing a Database

That whole like lowest

The lowest common denominator yes.

[LAUGH] Now I gotta back up and

So it's good to do anything.

What it's like to say okay,

53

And it's important that we

54

As you say, know where we're going.

55

Understand what it is we're trying
to accomplish in order to successful

What you don't want to do I think.

And I see this a lot and

It's very easy to fall in this trap

And you go to your computer and

64

65

66

So that's what we're gonna focus

71
00:03:41.800 --> 00:03:43.950
It's kind of we got, okay Y.

>> Right.
>> And

it's kind of like my opening sentence or

>> I'm not sure where

They're

like where you do like a small like-

78

>> Yeah, I think that's what it is.

79

>> Yes.
>> We'll go with thesis.

80

>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

>> I know that first paragraph has to

83
00:04:09.050 --> 00:04:10.210
>> Yes.
>> You follow the what is it,

84

the keyhole something?

85

>> I'm gonna look that up while

Ronnie's my grammar police, usually.

88
00:04:17.540 --> 00:04:20.010
All right, so yeah, we're gonna talk about
this process, so let's talk about it.

89

We'll take a look at how we discover our

94

And then, creating the relationship or

95
00:04:38.950 --> 00:04:42.720

96
00:04:42.720 --> 00:04:48.165
So, that first phase is, what I like to

97
00:04:48.165 --> 00:04:50.590
it that really describes what it is.

98
00:04:50.590 --> 00:04:53.500
The statement of purpose

99
00:04:53.500 --> 00:04:55.630
Why am I creating this database and

100

101

103

105
00:05:13.880 --> 00:05:16.490

107
00:05:18.190 --> 00:05:20.930

they might be my customer.

108
00:05:20.930 --> 00:05:23.300
Or it's the upper level management.

109
00:05:23.300 --> 00:05:26.210
Or I'm doing this as a freelance and

designing a database for them.

111
00:05:29.300 --> 00:05:30.730
I'm not designing it for me.

112
00:05:30.730 --> 00:05:34.740
I have to make sure that I
discuss this part with them and

113

114
00:05:37.170 --> 00:05:40.900
And this is a conversation you have to
have and sometimes you have to have it

115

116

00:05:53.630 --> 00:05:56.270

119
00:05:56.270 --> 00:05:58.698
Do you want B?
Do you want C, which one do we,

120
00:05:58.698 --> 00:06:00.330
what are you going with?

121
00:06:00.330 --> 00:06:04.590
And we actually had to get him on
the phone and talk it out and like so

122
00:06:04.590 --> 00:06:08.570

something?

123
00:06:08.570 --> 00:06:10.170
Okay, now understand.

124
00:06:10.170 --> 00:06:13.040
So now I can go ahead and
take the steps necessary

125
00:06:13.040 --> 00:06:14.840
that I need to get you to that end result
>> Yeah,

126
00:06:14.840 --> 00:06:19.090
that's a great example because in this
case, he was telling us what he wanted but

127
00:06:19.090 --> 00:06:21.040
we didn't understand what he wanted.

128
00:06:21.040 --> 00:06:23.340
Maybe we're not using the same language,

129
00:06:23.340 --> 00:06:28.100
he thinks he's being very clear but again,
it's a communication that has to occur.

130
00:06:28.100 --> 00:06:29.490
So that statement of purpose,

131
00:06:29.490 --> 00:06:33.050
sometimes you'll see this refered to

episodes.description: Mike and Vonne complete the initial design process of their database by determining which fields will be indexed for database optimization and storing unique values.  They also create a relationship matrix to help determine table relationships.
episodes.title: Designing a Database Part 3

episodes.description: Mike and Vonne take pen to paper and create a simple entity relationship (ER) diagram to help visualize the design of their database and relationships between tables. They examine each table relationship to determine their optionality and cardinality. In other words,  if the relationship is optional or required (optionality) as well as the type of relationship: one to one, one to many, many to many (cardinality). They also review different types of notation to represent relationships in ER diagrams.
episodes.title: Creating Database Models

episodes.description: Vonne and Mike continue drawing diagrams for the database. In this episode, they add more details to their ER diagram, which is referred to as the logical diagram or customer view. The detailed ER diagram is then used a roadmap to create the relational model (RM) diagram, which is also referred to as the physical diagram or developer view. They also created more tables, know as junction tables, to resolve many to many relationships.
episodes.title: Creating Database Models Part 2

episodes.description: Mike and Vonne double check all diagrams and other materials to finalize their database planning. They discuss naming conventions for tables and fields, the importance of documentation in your design process, and next steps for implementation.
episodes.title: Finalizing the Model

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Vonne discuss entity integrity and start creating tables using Access. They create fields in the tables, explaining the different data types as they go. They also introduce data constraints that can be placed on the fields and designate the primary keys in each table.
episodes.title: Entity Integrity

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Mike examine referential integrity. They create relationships between tables using primary and foreign keys and determine if referential integrity needs to be enforced on each relationship.
episodes.title: Referential Integrity

episodes.description: Mike and Vonne are back to discuss referential integrity, specifically covering cascading updates and cascading deletes.
episodes.title: Referential Integrity Part 2

WEBVTT

[MUSIC]

00:00:16.720 --> 00:00:18.448
I'm your host, Vonne Smith and

we are coming back with a Part Two

We had a little bit more to talk about and

00:00:26.137 --> 00:00:27.060
Mike Rodrick.

whatever you're using of course,

15
00:00:44.940 --> 00:00:46.920
but the concept is the same, right?

16
00:00:46.920 --> 00:00:50.840
Referential integrity is gonna
make sure of a few things, right?

17
00:00:50.840 --> 00:00:55.071
It's gonna keep that integrity
between our relationships or

18
00:00:55.071 --> 00:00:58.090

19

And remember what

20

That primary key is unique and not known,

22
00:01:07.940 --> 00:01:11.160
But I have another table that I wanna

24
00:01:15.070 --> 00:01:17.700

25
00:01:17.700 --> 00:01:23.620
And so we think about a customer's

26
00:01:23.620 --> 00:01:27.050
But in the orders table that customer
should place several orders.

27
00:01:27.050 --> 00:01:31.220
So you get that one to many relationship,
the customer ID in the customer's table.

28
00:01:31.220 --> 00:01:34.590
Is the primary key can only exist once,
it can't be null.

29
00:01:34.590 --> 00:01:38.420
But the customer ID and
the orders table is the foreign key.

30
00:01:38.420 --> 00:01:43.220
The copy of the primary key but
it can exist many times, right?

31
00:01:43.220 --> 00:01:48.055
And so we wanna make sure that that
relationship doesn't get lose it's

32

integrity and how could we do that?

33
00:01:50.620 --> 00:01:55.120
Well what if again thin about your
costumers and your orders table.

34
00:01:55.120 --> 00:01:59.880
What if I had a costumer and
say their ID is costumer one?

35
00:02:00.980 --> 00:02:04.800
And in my orders, today, well they've
placed several orders over the years.

36
00:02:04.800 --> 00:02:08.560
And it's referenced by or
the relationship's by the customer ID.

37
00:02:08.560 --> 00:02:11.090
Now I delete the customer
from the customer's table.

38
00:02:12.360 --> 00:02:16.765
Also and I've got all of these orders that
have a customer ID that supposed to tie

39
00:02:16.765 --> 00:02:18.560

40
00:02:18.560 --> 00:02:21.570
But that customer doesn't exist
anymore because somebody deleted it.

41
00:02:21.570 --> 00:02:26.350
Now I've got these orphaned records and
Ive lost my referential integrity or

42
00:02:26.350 --> 00:02:27.330

43
00:02:27.330 --> 00:02:29.440
What if I changed the customer ID?

44
00:02:30.590 --> 00:02:35.380
That didn't change the customer ID on all
those foreign key fields that it's in.

45
00:02:35.380 --> 00:02:37.850
And now again,
we've lost that referential integrity.

46
00:02:37.850 --> 00:02:40.370
>> Yeah and
we went through different examples

47
00:02:40.370 --> 00:02:45.540
as to why you would want to have
referential integrity or not.

48
00:02:45.540 --> 00:02:49.080
In a sense like okay, cuz when you were
just saying well there's still orders.

49
00:02:49.080 --> 00:02:54.030
But you might wanna keep the orders

50
00:02:54.030 --> 00:02:58.480
So I'm like, turn it off, but
hey if this customer goes away here and

51
00:02:58.480 --> 00:03:00.770
it's in the loyalty program, or whatever.

52
00:03:00.770 --> 00:03:03.950
That needs to go away together and

53
00:03:03.950 --> 00:03:08.290
that's why you want to have
referential integrity.

54
00:03:08.290 --> 00:03:12.220
But when we're doing that in Access I
remember there's two little check

55
00:03:12.220 --> 00:03:14.580

56
00:03:14.580 --> 00:03:17.600

>> That was the whole update and delete.

58

>> Yep.
>> So is that why we're back?

59
00:03:20.840 --> 00:03:23.022

>> Because I know we did

282
00:16:29.680 --> 00:16:33.120
do some auto numbering as far--
>> Every one of the other ones is,

283
00:16:33.120 --> 00:16:33.970
just this one.

284
00:16:33.970 --> 00:16:34.570
>> All right, good.
[LAUGH]

285
00:16:34.570 --> 00:16:36.330
>> And we did that intentionally so

286
00:16:36.330 --> 00:16:38.335
we could come back
around to show you this.

287
00:16:38.335 --> 00:16:39.460
[LAUGH]
>> All right.

288
00:16:39.460 --> 00:16:43.911
>> All right, so
that is cascade auto update, or cascade,

289
00:16:43.911 --> 00:16:47.870
I cannot talk, cascade updates, all right?

290
00:16:47.870 --> 00:16:52.880
If you update the primary key,
it will automatically update every place

291
00:16:52.880 --> 00:16:57.630
in the rest of the database that that
primary key is used, as a foreign key.

292
00:16:57.630 --> 00:17:01.910
Again, this only has to do with
primary keys and their references,

293
00:17:01.910 --> 00:17:02.620
the foreign keys.

294
00:17:02.620 --> 00:17:05.200
This isn't other fields or
anything like that.

295
00:17:05.200 --> 00:17:06.900
They should only be stored
once in your database, so

296
00:17:06.900 --> 00:17:09.780
you shouldn't have to worry
about doing cascade updates.

297
00:17:09.780 --> 00:17:11.860
Right, so that's the way that works.

298
00:17:11.860 --> 00:17:16.390
And I tell ya, it's something that you've
got to think of as an organization, right?

299
00:17:16.390 --> 00:17:19.440
Do you want to allow this,
does it work with this data,

300
00:17:19.440 --> 00:17:24.930
should I allow those changes,
because now I've lost all reference.

301
00:17:24.930 --> 00:17:28.810
Let's say his I.D used to be E-005, and

302
00:17:28.810 --> 00:17:33.070
I changed it to E-001,

303
00:17:33.070 --> 00:17:37.780
I haven't really lost all those,
but I could lose history somewhere.

304
00:17:37.780 --> 00:17:40.300
>> Well I'm thinking like
in work track changes.

305
00:17:40.300 --> 00:17:42.190
>> Yeah.
>> Like you can't just turn track changes,

306
00:17:42.190 --> 00:17:44.370
I mean do they have like log references or
whatever?

307
00:17:44.370 --> 00:17:47.860
>> Yeah, you'd have to set up a table to
where anything, if something was modified,

308
00:17:47.860 --> 00:17:52.160
you take the original first, put it in
another table and then let it be modified.

309
00:17:52.160 --> 00:17:53.760
>> It's obviously--
>> Modified, it'll--

310
00:17:53.760 --> 00:17:55.390
>> That's a little bit more advanced.

311
00:17:55.390 --> 00:17:56.780
>> Yeah.
>> But it is possible.

312
00:17:56.780 --> 00:17:57.780
>> It is possible.

313
00:17:57.780 --> 00:17:58.560
Yep.
>> But in this

314
00:17:58.560 --> 00:18:01.660
scenario that we're talking about
it's like, yeah, you've changed it.

315
00:18:01.660 --> 00:18:05.480
Tomorrow you come back, I don't
remember what his old employee ID was.

316
00:18:05.480 --> 00:18:09.470
And if I didn't notate that anywhere else,
then, yes.

317
00:18:09.470 --> 00:18:12.110
>> It could be an issue, exactly.

318
00:18:12.110 --> 00:18:14.180
So that's the cascading updates.

319
00:18:14.180 --> 00:18:18.610
Now if we go back and
look at that relationship property again,

320
00:18:18.610 --> 00:18:21.800
so there's also an option for
cascaded delete.

321
00:18:21.800 --> 00:18:25.810
And I'm going to tell you, I'm
a proponent of cascading updates, right?

322
00:18:25.810 --> 00:18:29.530
I like that, most of the time it's
not going to get you in trouble

323
00:18:29.530 --> 00:18:31.290
because like I said we really don't lose,

324
00:18:31.290 --> 00:18:35.340
I didn't lose the fact that he is
set up to teach these classes.

325
00:18:35.340 --> 00:18:39.821
It changed his employee ID number and I
don't know what his trainer ID is anymore,

326
00:18:39.821 --> 00:18:43.340
the old one was, but
maybe I don't really care and

327
00:18:43.340 --> 00:18:45.690
again I don't really lose anything.

328
00:18:45.690 --> 00:18:51.110
But this one,
cascade delete related records,

329
00:18:51.110 --> 00:18:53.870
you can probably infer
what that's going to do.

330
00:18:53.870 --> 00:18:58.420
I cannot delete a record if the primary
key is being referenced as a foreign key

331
00:18:58.420 --> 00:18:59.410
in any other table.

332
00:18:59.410 --> 00:19:02.820
In other words, what's his name,
James, I think?

333
00:19:02.820 --> 00:19:03.620
>> Yes.
[LAUGH]

334
00:19:03.620 --> 00:19:05.030
>> Has been inserted into

335
00:19:05.030 --> 00:19:07.960
the classes trainers calendar,
so I can't delete

336
00:19:07.960 --> 00:19:12.070
his record because his record is being
referenced by that classes trainers table.

337
00:19:12.070 --> 00:19:14.040
Cascade delete, if I enable this,

338
00:19:14.040 --> 00:19:17.600
will say all right, instead of
preventing you from deleting it,

339
00:19:17.600 --> 00:19:21.312
because it will leave orphaned records,
what I'll do is I'll delete the one you

340
00:19:21.312 --> 00:19:25.370
want to delete, and I'll delete any
record that has a reference back to it.

341
00:19:25.370 --> 00:19:27.900
Now you don't have any orphaned records.

342
00:19:27.900 --> 00:19:31.550
But you also just deleted
a lot of information, right?

343
00:19:31.550 --> 00:19:34.120
>> Yeah, I totally see what you're saying,

344
00:19:34.120 --> 00:19:38.140
and I guess there's, I'm always
thinking I can think on the flip

345
00:19:38.140 --> 00:19:41.940
side of why there might be reasons
why you would want that to happen.

346
00:19:41.940 --> 00:19:46.620
If this is like your active,
maybe somehow there's,

347
00:19:46.620 --> 00:19:48.360
I'm thinking like college classes or
whatever?

348
00:19:48.360 --> 00:19:50.010
Like this is what the students see.

349
00:19:50.010 --> 00:19:50.790
This is what we see.

350
00:19:50.790 --> 00:19:55.405
Well, if we cancel the class, if we delete
it here, it better be deleted here.

351
00:19:55.405 --> 00:19:59.800
Because we don't want the students
seeing a class that we are not running.

352
00:20:01.320 --> 00:20:05.260
So there's situations where
you'd want it that way too.

353
00:20:05.260 --> 00:20:06.430
>> Definitely, yeah.

354
00:20:06.430 --> 00:20:09.870
And so there's [LAUGH].

355
00:20:09.870 --> 00:20:11.980
>> We're just having all sorts
of fun with words, right?

356
00:20:11.980 --> 00:20:12.730
>> I tell you what.

357
00:20:12.730 --> 00:20:14.310
English is my first language too.

358
00:20:14.310 --> 00:20:16.900
It is my only language,
I don't even do it well.

359
00:20:16.900 --> 00:20:18.690
But yes, exactly right.

360
00:20:18.690 --> 00:20:24.230
So there are gonna be some times when
we might want to use cascading delete.

361
00:20:24.230 --> 00:20:28.335
Just keep that in mind that
you can end up losing data,

362
00:20:28.335 --> 00:20:30.440
because if this is a customer's database,

363
00:20:30.440 --> 00:20:35.170
all right, or an orders database for
a sales company and I've got customers and

00:20:35.170 --> 00:20:37.630
I've got a table with all
the orders they've placed with us.

365
00:20:37.630 --> 00:20:40.820
Well, let's say business
XYZ is out of business.

366
00:20:40.820 --> 00:20:42.970
They've closed their doors, so

367
00:20:42.970 --> 00:20:46.170
we're not going to be able to sell to
them anymore, I want to remove them from

368
00:20:46.170 --> 00:20:50.950
the customer's table because I don't want
any of my sales people calling on them,

369
00:20:50.950 --> 00:20:54.380
because they're not in business anymore,
so I want to delete their record.

370
00:20:54.380 --> 00:20:57.610
So I can't delete it because
there's records referencing it, so

371
00:20:57.610 --> 00:21:00.540
I turn on cascade delete,
now I delete it, and

372
00:21:00.540 --> 00:21:03.310
it deletes the history of all those
orders that they've placed with us.

373
00:21:03.310 --> 00:21:04.730
And those are gone forever, right?

374
00:21:04.730 --> 00:21:09.770
>> Yeah, I think with both of these,
the update and the delete, it's great

375
00:21:09.770 --> 00:21:15.640
when you need it, but
it has a potential to really mess you up.

376
00:21:15.640 --> 00:21:17.560
This can be very dangerous.

377
00:21:17.560 --> 00:21:21.570
>> It can be.
>> Depending on what is important

378
00:21:21.570 --> 00:21:23.330
of how you're storing your data.

379
00:21:23.330 --> 00:21:26.530
So it can go both ways on this one.

380
00:21:26.530 --> 00:21:30.900
>> And it is something that you can turn
on, use, and then turn back off, too.

381
00:21:30.900 --> 00:21:32.660
Like referential integrity
I will leave on.

382
00:21:32.660 --> 00:21:38.030
That stays on to make sure I maintain the
fact that the primary key has to exist,

383
00:21:38.030 --> 00:21:39.700
and things like that.

384
00:21:39.700 --> 00:21:42.570
But the cascading updating tasks and
cascading deletes,

385
00:21:42.570 --> 00:21:45.270
I might turn it on just to do one
thing and then turn it back off so

386
00:21:45.270 --> 00:21:49.620
nobody else accidentally updates a record
and updates all these other records.

387
00:21:49.620 --> 00:21:53.980
You can set it up so that you can trigger
cascading across multiple tables.

388
00:21:53.980 --> 00:21:57.800
You make one change, and
that triggers a change on another table,

389
00:21:57.800 --> 00:22:01.920
which triggers a change on another table,
which triggers a change on another table,

390
00:22:01.920 --> 00:22:05.220
and it's great if that's
what you needed to do.

391
00:22:05.220 --> 00:22:07.440
It's really scary if you didn't
know that was set up to do that.

392
00:22:07.440 --> 00:22:13.130
>> And I've been in situations where it's
one of those, I can do certain things.

00:22:13.130 --> 00:22:17.670
But if I really wanted
something to not exist anymore,

00:22:17.670 --> 00:22:22.370

00:22:22.370 --> 00:22:25.190
I had to call somebody had
to like sign off on it.

00:22:25.190 --> 00:22:29.030
And then it was only if I

00:22:29.030 --> 00:22:33.870

398
00:22:33.870 --> 00:22:38.340
That and it like completely
existed across all these

399
00:22:39.410 --> 00:22:42.820
different places, but I couldn't do it.

00:22:42.820 --> 00:22:45.080
No, you had to have the master key.

00:22:45.080 --> 00:22:48.130
>> He probably turned it on just for
him to do it, then turned it back off.

402
00:22:48.130 --> 00:22:48.660
>> Exactly.

403
00:22:48.660 --> 00:22:51.180
Yeah, I'm like yeah,
I can see him checking the box off.

404
00:22:51.180 --> 00:22:54.100
>> All right, so let's test it out.

405
00:22:54.100 --> 00:22:58.760
Let's go in here and we've already seen

00:22:58.760 --> 00:23:03.560
It did update right if we

00:23:03.560 --> 00:23:07.380
I try to delete James,

it says no because there

00:23:12.100 --> 00:23:14.950
So we're going to turn on which means I

00:23:16.260 --> 00:23:17.260
We're going to come back in here and

00:23:17.260 --> 00:23:23.170

delete related records, I'll click okay,

00:23:23.170 --> 00:23:27.520
we're going to open up trainers and

414
00:23:27.520 --> 00:23:32.025
So again there is two records

00:23:32.025 --> 00:23:34.730
but I'm going to delete him again.

00:23:36.150 --> 00:23:40.700
It's going warn me, I get one warning,

00:23:40.700 --> 00:23:43.522
Reference and
integrity rules would be violated.

00:23:43.522 --> 00:23:44.588
Wait, did I turn it on?

Let me check that again.

Let's go back in there.

00:23:50.605 --> 00:23:53.945
Cascade delete related records and

And we're going to go back to Trainers.

00:23:58.483 --> 00:24:03.009
I mean because of the, I don't know if the

00:24:13.020 --> 00:24:16.680
So not only are the related

00:24:40.550 --> 00:24:41.697

00:24:43.250 --> 00:24:48.440
>> So now all of a sudden,
I would have to actually turn

00:24:54.613 --> 00:24:59.871

It's not just between here and here,

00:25:09.820 --> 00:25:12.435
And how they kind of interweave together,

00:25:12.435 --> 00:25:14.790
that's why I think it's barking at you.

>> If you look at it,

So one of those records in

Puppy Kindergarten, so let's go

00:25:53.494 --> 00:25:55.600

00:25:57.430 --> 00:26:00.834

00:28:04.189 --> 00:28:04.689

episodes.description: Mike and Vonne discuss domain integrity. They examine the different fields in their tables and determine ways to control the integrity of the data that can be entered. They impose different data constraints, apply input masks and formats, and create lookup lists.
episodes.title: Domain Integrity

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Mike continue to look at the fields in the database and determine how to enforce domain integrity. They expand on lookup lists by creating combo boxes with queries as the row source type. They also cover the different options to control the combo boxes.
episodes.title: Domain Integrity Part 2

episodes.description: Mike and Vonne are back with more domain integrity. They have a lot of fun solving a problem encountered with a lookup list by adjusting tables relationships and field properties. A must see episode in database planning.
episodes.title: Domain Integrity Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Mike cover unique and required constraints on fields. They also discuss the difference between a null value and a zero length string (blank).
episodes.title: Domain Integrity Part 4

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Vonne introduce queries. They write simple SQL statements to retrieve information from the tables based on certain criteria. They cover the keywords SELECT, FROM, WHERE, AND, OR.
episodes.title: Getting Started with Queries

episodes.description: Mike and Vonne continue with queries, specifically covering dates, date ranges, and sorting. They cover the keywords IN, BETWEEN, ORDER BY, ASC, DESC.
episodes.title: Getting Started with Queries Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Mike discuss pattern matching by using the LIKE keyword and different wildcard characters. They demonstrate the many possibilities of how wildcard characters can change the results of the query.
episodes.title: Getting Started with Queries Part 3

episodes.description: Mike and Vonne take queries to the next level. In this episode, they introduce the following joins: inner, left outer, and right outer. They specifically demonstrate how to write a query with an inner join.
episodes.title: Querying Multiple Tables

episodes.description: Mike and Vonne continue writing multiple table queries.  They walk through a demonstration of a more complex inner join.
episodes.title: Querying Multiple Tables Part 2

episodes.description: In this final episode, Vonne and Mike discuss the complicated world of left outer joins and right outer joins.
episodes.title: Querying Multiple Tables Part 3
